title: Marvel Just Dropped TWO New Games and Fans Are Schocked!

rawLines.text: [Music]
There's two new Marvel games coming. So,
the first one that was announced was a
fighting game called Marvel Token. I am
really surprised to see this, why you
would have a 2D fighter. I'm hearing
things about 2KXO, which is Riots
fighter, and that this has really made
them afraid. There's questions about why
this versus Marvel vs. Capcom, which has
kind of perfected this. The character
art looks great. So, for whatever
reason, that was announced recently. And
there's another one coming to mobile.
It's a semi-action RPG that NEI is
developing called Mystic Mayhem where
you have three characters, but you're
also using abilities with real-time
elements. You could use Clash Royale
potentially as a shorthand reference,
although it's a radically different
mechanic. There's that level of
real-time element. And not only that,
there was a confirmation at least from
IGN that after the cancellation of Black
Panther, EA is still making three three
Marvel games. Wow. So, it is still a
bonanza. And I'm confused because the IP
has never been weaker. Like
Thunderbolt's returns in the box office
were not good. That was not a great
check-in with the MCU. So, I'm very
surprised to see all these activities
going on in franchise Marvel Land. Well,
it's what we talk about all the time
that, you know, in today's world, IP
still works and still draws people in,
reduces some of your, you know, CPI
costs because you've got that. I mean, I
think, God, I think there's something
like 30 games with Marvel licenses out
in the world. I don't think we're going
to see a slowing of this, you know. Same
thing with Star Wars. I think we're
going to still see IP leading with a
bunch of games. Yeah. I don't know.
These actually these two games, the
Marvel games look actually pretty good.
Now that this is shovelware, this is
really high quality product all of them.
Maming gaming takes over as a good
representation of the IP since Disney
seems to be screwing it up every single
year from an entertainment standpoint.
Yeah. I mean, yeah. So, I don't know.
We'll carry the torch for a while until
Disney gets their act together. I don't
know. So, one last check-in before we
leave. And I was really surprised to see
this not just announced, but it looks
like it's launched. Although we'll see
next week if I got this one wrong, but
it appears that Whittle Defender, which
we had checked in a couple weeks ago
from Habby, has launched. I was really
surprised to see this. This is the one
where you have characters in the center
of a map, very similar to a game called
The Tower, which has been scaling for a
number of years now, and you're choosing
abilities as waves of enemy come enemies
come towards you. So, imagine taking
Survivor.io and really moving the agency
to move around, but still keeping a lot
of those rogike abilities. I was super
high on the game, but I was surprised to
see them get this out the door this
quickly. It would actually been in
pre-registration for a little bit. So,
one quick excuse is just to check it
back in with Happy, like why they chose
to hit the go button on this, which I
was surprised by because both Cappy Bear
Go and Archer 2 are in a really good
place. They have hit, I would argue,
equilibrium when it comes to at least
daily active users, and we see revenue
starting to flatline as well. and
they're looking like a group pair of
games that are going to do around 600
million at least just in net IP revenue
with ads thrown on top. And so this
company, as we were talking about, is
getting very close to getting on the top
20 publisher lists globally. And looks
like it might be heading towards a
billion dollar in and run rate. So
surprised to hit the go button on this
so quickly. The Fatoule is a disaster. I
just don't understand how they ship
this. I think it's because their timing.
So, so the key issue is like the length
of the levels. And because you don't
have real-time elements, I think the
length is maybe the same as like in an
archer room, but remember you're going
through 40 different rooms in Archer.
And this might have a similar length,
but because you're not moving, it feels
like it's going much slower. And so the
first Fatoule levels, normally you'd
want quick feedback for the player. You
want to establish the loop. And you
really had to sit there for, I would
argue, what maybe three or four minutes
while waves of enemies were coming at
you. And you can't 2x or 3x until the
third or fourth battle. I I was
surprised to see them like make a choice
like that. Usually they're pretty good
at getting these metas out the door. The
monetization doesn't feel as strong
right now. I expected to be hit with a
lot more passes. This is one of the
marquee things Heavy does that people
should really look at is that they had a
lot of recurring monthly passes that are
annuities. So I get a bundle of gems
delivered to me every single day by
paying an upfront price. Like annuities
are something that they've really put
back on the table, but I still see very
few people like pursuing the happy meta
or incorporating elements from that. the
emphasis on leaderboards as big in
Archer 2, like literally just straight
up ranking power score. They've just
been refining this meta over and over
again and people start learning from
them. And I think they'll do it again
with Widow Defender, but this is such a
bizarre launch that I have, you know,
heart palpitations from Squad Busters.
This is like shift something out the
door. And look at they've done other
games like SSS Snaker, which I, you
know, probably wasn't in a place that
they were ready to jump 300 million in,
but they're like, "Hey, let's just shove
it out. We can take more shots on goal
when we have this meta established.
Watching some gameplay again. I'm just
struck by art style. And what's the
other one? Kingshot that we talk about.
Yeah, we haven't gotten into a full
conversation about that. That is another
very interesting game. That's part of
the 4X meta. Oh my god, I've been
playing that game non-stop. Kingshot.
Oh, I'm Yeah, I'm even spending money on
that. It's like I have to admit though,
it is kind of a poor man's 4X game. It's
not like as egregious as other Forex
games. Hab's done an exceptional job.
Those guys are crushing it right now.
Yeah, I think there is something to God
the change in the art style and what is
appropriate for what we would call a
midcore game. You know, they're using
this like super cute casual bright art
style. Don't forget that they invented
the term hyper casual. Like Archer was
the original hyper casual. Like that was
one of the first doof articles. You go
back and listen to it. Still very
insightful. So I think like they get
marketing, they get meta, and that's the
secret to a lot of this, like combining
those two things on mobile. I do. I
mean, I remember playing Survivor.io for
the first time, and I'm like, "Oh, this
is like super easy." And then the next
thing I know, I was in the deepest
monetization pit optimizing all of my
gear, you know, in 10 different slots.
And I was like, "Oh, wow." like I've
just entered, you know, a deep midcore
game and and this looks cute. This looks
like a I shouldn't use the word cute. I
mean, it is visually cute, but it looks
like you've got some, you know, rogike
with three characters on the screen,
enemy waves coming at you. You know, I
imagine you optimize the hell out of all
your slots. Very easy to make a meta
around this. Very easy to do roambo,
elemental damage, rock, paper, scissors,
shoot. Like, they have the right
elements here. And remember, it's
passive gameplay, which opens up a lot
of opportunities. Like, for instance, to
have the auto play, to have the 5x, 4x,
10x speed booster. This is my kind of
game, dude. You don't have to do
nothing. It just does. It plays itself,
you know? Like I don't have to like move
around the screen or worry about being
all stressed out about arcade [ __ ]
Yeah. What I didn't like about Survivor
IO is you're moving around the screen
and you could be playing for 20 minutes
and then the session lengths were insane
there, too. I guess that's another great
point, Jen, is they didn't even break it
up like Archer at least has like almost
exit points naturally between rooms
where you're selecting abilities. But
surro.io is brutal. Yeah. No, I would
like just throw the my phone because I
would die 20 minutes in and I'm like,
"Oh, you assholes." Like you That's the
thing that I don't know gets me as a
player is that I have now wasted my time
and died. And I guess that's where, you
know, have monetization because you just
let me pay and I don't die. But no, this
is cute. This is But I just think that
we should do a little more around I
should talk to Stan at Beta Head. What
is going on with this art style,
you know, just dominating for midcore
games? Can you imagine 10 years ago
going to dude like hardcore gamers and
being like, "Hey, yeah, is this art
style for you?" Everyone would be like,
"No, that's for like an 8-year-old." But
it just seems to really I don't know. I
wonder what's going on. I don't I don't
think it's that bad. I mean, they kind
of look like tech dudes
or tech dudes. Like little thumbs. I
don't remember what you're talking What
are you talking about? Tech dudes. Oh,
tech. Yeah. Yeah. I mean, that was a
great toy line back in the day. Tech was
the skateboards, not the Yeah, but those
they look both look like thumbs. The
wittle. Yeah, cuz you cuz you played
with the idea was that you played with
the skate. Look at you with that toy
reference. I'm digging this, Phil. I had
a childhood at one point I experienced
this.
No, that's a good one. No. Yeah, I don't
know. Like I think there's a some sort
of shift going on in the appeal of
different themes and IP that is making
me super curious. Anyway, thank you
everyone and we will see you next week.
[Music]
